texts.shortText:
As the scientific name suggests colonies can be very variable in morphology, but are hard, calcareous and light-pink to dull -orange in colour. Sections of the colony often take the form of flat undulating sheets, but other sections grow upwards into blunt, projecting and branching finger-like lobes. They are usually securely attached to hard substrata, usually the undersides of rocks or vertical rock faces, but can also overgrow other sedentary invertebrates.

When viewed closely the zooecia are distinctive and are elongate rectangular and dotted with conspicuous round pores. The small round apertures are each guarded by a pair of tiny aviculae which form an arch over the opening.
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 3-6 cm across.

Global: Endemic to South Africa (although fossils under this name reported from New Zealand).

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Cape Infanta.
Few details available. Fairly commonly found in low shore pools and down to 600 m depth.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites.

The form of the zooecia is diagnostic, but in the field easily confused with the Cylindrical false coral Tubicellopora cylindriformes, which forms similar hard, upright, finger-like processes and is often present under the same rocks. That species is salmon â€“ pink in colour though and has quite different cylindrical, projecting zooecia with large, round apertures.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 140).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129, as Gigantopora polymorpha).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 41).
